text: The analysis of ionome denoted that our hydroponic experiment mimicked the mine soil conditions because in both settings we obtained similar patterns in the leaf nutrient composition of the different accessions (Supplementary **Figure 3).

text: Loss-of-function alleles of HAC1 were unable to complement the high leaf arsenic of Kr-0 in F1 hybrids (Figure 2G), whereas the Col-0 At2g21045 genomic fragment introduced transgenically into Kr-0 was able to complement (Figure 2H), confirming that At2g21045 is the causal gene for HAC1.

text: First, although EMMA appears to produce a P-value distribution that conforms to the null expectation (except for extreme values; see Supplementary Figs12–118), it seems almost certain that some confounding remains (see below).

text: This observation supports our conclusion that HAC1 acts as an arsenate reductase in roots that controls arsenic accumulation in both roots and shoots when plants are exposed to arsenate.

text: In the absence of a functional HAC1 protein, A. thaliana still maintains the ability to reduce substantial amounts of arsenate to arsenite, suggesting that there are other arsenate reduction mechanisms in the plant.

text: These observations, taken together with the fact that arsenate accumulates in roots of plants lacking HAC1, strongly suggests that HAC1 encodes an arsenate reductase enzyme.

text: Furthermore, transformation of Col-0 wild type with a HAC1[Col-0]-Green Fluorescent Protein (HAC1[Col-0]-GFP) construct expressed from the HAC1 promoter allowed the detection of the HAC1-GFP fusion protein, which we observed to be localised to root hairs and epidermal cells at the surface of the root and to the pericycle within the stele (Figure 6C, 6E and Figure S3).

text: This population was created by crossing the high leaf arsenic accession Krefeld (Kr-0, CS28419), with a C at Chr2:9008060, to Col-0 that contains average leaf arsenic and has a T at Chr2:9008060.

text: Using genome-wide association (GWA) mapping of loci controlling natural variation in arsenic accumulation in Arabidopsis thaliana allowed us to identify the arsenate reductase required for this reduction, which we named High Arsenic Content 1 (HAC1).

text: An important condition for natural selection to act upon a trait is that this trait has phenotypic variation which is genetically determined.
